issue.name: Frameable response (potential Clickjacking)
issue.issueBackground:
It might be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the content of this response within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may enable a "clickjacking" attack, in which the attacker's page overlays the target application's interface with a different interface provided by the attacker. By inducing victim users to perform actions such as mouse clicks and keystrokes, the attacker can cause them to unwittingly carry out actions within the application that is being targeted. This technique allows the attacker to circumvent defenses against cross-site request forgery, and may result in unauthorized actions.

Note that this issue is being reported because the application's response does not set a suitable X-Frame-Options header in order to prevent framing attacks. Some applications attempt to prevent these attacks from within the HTML page itself, using "framebusting" code. However, this type of defense is normally ineffective and can usually be circumvented by a skilled attacker.
issue.remediationBackground:
You should review the application functions that are accessible from within the response, and determine whether they can be used by application users to perform any sensitive actions within the application. If so, then a framing attack targeting this response may result in unauthorized actions.

To effectively prevent framing attacks, the application should return a response header with the name X-Frame-Options and the value DENY to prevent framing altogether, or the value SAMEORIGIN to allow framing only by pages on the same origin as the response itself.

BenPal￢ﾄﾢ Your benefits friend

Accessibility

JLT Online Benefits aims to give all users a simple and user-friendly experience in the BenPal website.

To ensure this is the case, we have designed the site with a variety of accessibility features to make it easier to view and navigate for people with poor eyesight, blindness or other physical disabilities.

Please let us know if you have any questions, suggestions or other feedback to help us continue to improve the experience for all BenPal users.

The table below highlights some of the features that have been built in to the site to help navigation and usability through text-only browsers, keyboard navigation and for screen reader users.

Images

  • All content images have descriptive alt attributes
  • Solely decorative graphics have empty alt attributes

Font sizes

Change size through your browser:

  • Internet Explorer - select View, Text Size and then choose the preferred size
  • Firefox – select View, Zoom, Zoom In/Out

Forms

  • All forms follow a logical tab sequence
  • All labels that are associated with fields use HTML label tabs.

Scripting

Javascript is used to enhance usability but it is possible to browse the site without Javascript. All labels that are associated with fields use HTML label tabs.

Useful information

  • W3 Accessibility Guidelines
  • RNIB Web Accessibility

If you have a disability, you can get additional software and equipment to help you use your computer and gain more access to websites:

  • Links – free text-only web browser for sighted users with low bandwidth
  • Lynx – free text-only web browser for blind users with refreshable Braille displays
  • JAWS – screen reader for Windows
  • VoiceOver – screen reader for Mac
  • Windows-Eyes – screen reader for Windows

issue.name: Email addresses disclosed
issue.issueBackground:
The presence of email addresses within application responses does not necessarily constitute a security vulnerability. Email addresses may appear intentionally within contact information, and many applications (such as web mail) include arbitrary third-party email addresses within their core content.

However, email addresses of developers and other individuals (whether appearing on-screen or hidden within page source) may disclose information that is useful to an attacker; for example, they may represent usernames that can be used at the application's login, and they may be used in social engineering attacks against the organization's personnel. Unnecessary or excessive disclosure of email addresses may also lead to an increase in the volume of spam email received.
issue.remediationBackground: You should review the email addresses being disclosed by the application, and consider removing any that are unnecessary, or replacing personal addresses with anonymous mailbox addresses (such as helpdesk@example.com).
issue.issueDetail:
The following email address was disclosed in the response:
  • support@benpal.com

BenPal￢ﾄﾢ Your benefits friend

Privacy

JLT Benefit Solutions Limited ("JLTBS", "our," "us" and "we") has created this privacy policy in order to communicate our commitment to the privacy of information provided to us by our employer clients and their employees. We understand the nature of the information entrusted to us and acknowledge that maintenance of the privacy of such information is of the highest importance to our clients and their employees. The following discloses our information gathering and dissemination practices in relation to the services we provide through or in connection with the website that you have accessed using the special benefits icon, https://www.benpal.com ("Website" and "our Services").

Our Information Practices

We collect, use and disclose the following categories of information in the following ways:

1. Company Contact Information

When clients and prospective clients engage us or inquire about our Services, we ask them to provide us with company contact information, some examples of which are the company's name, address, number of employees and industry classification. We use company contact information to provide information to clients and prospective clients (paper and electronic) in relation to our Services and to maintain a record of inquiries regarding our Services.

2. Information we collect and how we use it

When your employer decides to use our Services to enable you to join and manage your employee benefits, your employer provides us with information which includes, but is not limited to, your name, address, NI number, title, salary, commencement of employment and information regarding your employment. We may also ask for details of your spouse, partner or other immediate family member if they are to be included as the beneficiary of a policy or product. Where you submit such details, you do so on behalf of the relevant family member and you acknowledge and accept that it is your responsibility for letting them know (i) that you have done so, (ii) what details you have submitted and (iii) the purpose of submitting the details. It is your responsibility to keep your personal details and those of any relevant family member updated. If we require sensitive personal data, we will ensure that the collection and use is in strict accordance with the "application legislation" principles of data protection and data privacy.

If you do not wish us to hold your personal data in order to use our Services, please send a blank email to removedata@benpal.com

We gather this information to allow us to process your enrolment, provide you with updated details of your employee benefits, to assist you in applying for further benefits or products and to allow us to process those applications. When you apply for any benefits and/or products offered through the Website, we will pass your personal details and those of your beneficiary, where applicable, to the provider of those benefits and/or products. Thereafter, the provider may correspond with you directly. Information we have gathered from your employer and you may also be used by us to communicate with you on any matter relating to your benefits and the provision of our Services in general.

Your employer has provided us with your business e-mail address in order for us to communicate your benefit offering and our services. E-mail messages sent over the Internet cannot be guaranteed to be completely secure as they may be subject to possible interception or loss. If you do not want to be contacted on your business e-mail address, please send a blank email to noemail@benpal.com

We may also aggregate employee information from multiple employer clients to monitor Website usage, assist us to develop our services and to analyse performance. Examples of analyses performed include, but are not limited to: number of employees enrolled in plans provided by a particular insurance carrier, average number of employees employed by our clients and average number of benefit plans sponsored by our clients. When used to perform such analyses, information provided by an employer customer or its employees is never disclosed in a level of detail sufficient to permit the identification of any individual employer customer or individual employee record.

From time to time, we may provide your information to our client service agencies for research and analysis purposes so that we can monitor and improve the service we provide. We, or our agents and sub-contractors may contact you by post, e-mail or telephone to ask you for your feedback and comments on our service.

We may also wish to provide you with information about special features of our Website, our Services or other services. If you do not want to receive this information go to "My Account" and select "Preferences" to turn this service off.

3. Login Identification/Passwords

Our Services require users to choose a username and password in order to activate their account and these will be the login credentials to access the Website. You agree to maintain the confidentiality of your username and password and agreed to notify us immediately should you become aware of any unauthorised use of your username, password, account or information on the Website. You are responsible for the security of your username and password and JLT accepts no responsibility howsoever arising and will not be liable for any and all activities that occur under your account to the extent that they result from your failure to comply with this paragraph.

4. Cookies

As part of our high security standards, when you enter the Website we will use cookies. Cookies are small pieces of information that are stored on your computer, and are held until you close your browser, log off our Website, or the session automatically expires. The cookie does not contain any personal or confidential data about you. Most browsers are initially set up to accept cookies. You can set your browser to refuse cookies, however, if you choose this setting you will be unable to use our Website.

5. Service Activity Logging

All transactions conducted through the Website will be monitored and recorded for the purposes of logging Website usage, diagnosing problems, enhancing features and functionality of the Services and for other legitimate business purposes.

Security

Our Website is secured by firewalls and IDPS (Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems) to prevent the loss, misuse and alteration of the information under our control. Our web servers are located in a high security Data Centre professionally managed by a third party vendor. The servers on which we store personally-identifiable information are kept in a secure environment in independently-lockable racks. Our Data Centre has multi-layered physical access controls, CCTV surveillance and formal physical security access procedures.

This Website takes every precaution to protect our users' information. We use the highest level of Internet-standard encryption technology to ensure the confidentiality of your data during transmission and to protect it against tampering and message forgery. This process is known as SSL/TLS (Secure Sockets Layer/Transport Layer Security) and we are constantly updating our technology to provide you with the maximum practicable level of security. 

To check that you are in the secure area of our site, look in the bottom right of your browser and you will see a closed padlock or an unbroken key. You can inspect our certificate by clicking on this icon to verify that the site you are using is genuine.

Notification of Changes

If we decide to change our Privacy Policy, we will post those changes on this page and may place notices on other page of our Website, so that you are aware of the information we collect and how we use it at all times. Continued use of the Website will signify that you agree to any such changes. If at any point we decide to use or disclose information we have collected in a manner different from that stated at the time it was collected, we will notify you.

Transfer of data outside of the European Economic Area (EEA)

Where we transfer personal data to service providers or advisors outside of the EEA we will ensure that the recipient provides appropriate technical and organisational measures to safeguard against the unauthorised or unlawful processing of personal data and its accidental loss, destruction or damage. However, such information may be accessible by law enforcement agencies and other authorities in those countries to prevent and detect crime and comply with legal obligations.

Contact Information

If you have any questions about this privacy policy or the practices of this Website please send an email to support@benpal.com

issue.name: SSL cookie without secure flag set
issue.issueBackground: If the secure flag is set on a cookie, then browsers will not submit the cookie in any requests that use an unencrypted HTTP connection, thereby preventing the cookie from being trivially intercepted by an attacker monitoring network traffic. If the secure flag is not set, then the cookie will be transmitted in clear-text if the user visits any HTTP URLs within the cookie's scope. An attacker may be able to induce this event by feeding a user suitable links, either directly or via another web site. Even if the domain which issued the cookie does not host any content that is accessed over HTTP, an attacker may be able to use links of the form http://example.com:443/ to perform the same attack.
issue.remediationBackground: The secure flag should be set on all cookies that are used for transmitting sensitive data when accessing content over HTTPS. If cookies are used to transmit session tokens, then areas of the application that are accessed over HTTPS should employ their own session handling mechanism, and the session tokens used should never be transmitted over unencrypted communications.

BenPal￢ﾄﾢ Your benefits friend

Privacy

JLT Benefit Solutions Limited ("JLTBS", "our," "us" and "we") has created this privacy policy in order to communicate our commitment to the privacy of information provided to us by our employer clients and their employees. We understand the nature of the information entrusted to us and acknowledge that maintenance of the privacy of such information is of the highest importance to our clients and their employees. The following discloses our information gathering and dissemination practices in relation to the services we provide through or in connection with the website that you have accessed using the special benefits icon, https://www.benpal.com ("Website" and "our Services").

Our Information Practices

We collect, use and disclose the following categories of information in the following ways:

1. Company Contact Information

When clients and prospective clients engage us or inquire about our Services, we ask them to provide us with company contact information, some examples of which are the company's name, address, number of employees and industry classification. We use company contact information to provide information to clients and prospective clients (paper and electronic) in relation to our Services and to maintain a record of inquiries regarding our Services.

2. Information we collect and how we use it

When your employer decides to use our Services to enable you to join and manage your employee benefits, your employer provides us with information which includes, but is not limited to, your name, address, NI number, title, salary, commencement of employment and information regarding your employment. We may also ask for details of your spouse, partner or other immediate family member if they are to be included as the beneficiary of a policy or product. Where you submit such details, you do so on behalf of the relevant family member and you acknowledge and accept that it is your responsibility for letting them know (i) that you have done so, (ii) what details you have submitted and (iii) the purpose of submitting the details. It is your responsibility to keep your personal details and those of any relevant family member updated. If we require sensitive personal data, we will ensure that the collection and use is in strict accordance with the "application legislation" principles of data protection and data privacy.

If you do not wish us to hold your personal data in order to use our Services, please send a blank email to removedata@benpal.com

We gather this information to allow us to process your enrolment, provide you with updated details of your employee benefits, to assist you in applying for further benefits or products and to allow us to process those applications. When you apply for any benefits and/or products offered through the Website, we will pass your personal details and those of your beneficiary, where applicable, to the provider of those benefits and/or products. Thereafter, the provider may correspond with you directly. Information we have gathered from your employer and you may also be used by us to communicate with you on any matter relating to your benefits and the provision of our Services in general.

Your employer has provided us with your business e-mail address in order for us to communicate your benefit offering and our services. E-mail messages sent over the Internet cannot be guaranteed to be completely secure as they may be subject to possible interception or loss. If you do not want to be contacted on your business e-mail address, please send a blank email to noemail@benpal.com

We may also aggregate employee information from multiple employer clients to monitor Website usage, assist us to develop our services and to analyse performance. Examples of analyses performed include, but are not limited to: number of employees enrolled in plans provided by a particular insurance carrier, average number of employees employed by our clients and average number of benefit plans sponsored by our clients. When used to perform such analyses, information provided by an employer customer or its employees is never disclosed in a level of detail sufficient to permit the identification of any individual employer customer or individual employee record.

From time to time, we may provide your information to our client service agencies for research and analysis purposes so that we can monitor and improve the service we provide. We, or our agents and sub-contractors may contact you by post, e-mail or telephone to ask you for your feedback and comments on our service.

We may also wish to provide you with information about special features of our Website, our Services or other services. If you do not want to receive this information go to "My Account" and select "Preferences" to turn this service off.

3. Login Identification/Passwords

Our Services require users to choose a username and password in order to activate their account and these will be the login credentials to access the Website. You agree to maintain the confidentiality of your username and password and agreed to notify us immediately should you become aware of any unauthorised use of your username, password, account or information on the Website. You are responsible for the security of your username and password and JLT accepts no responsibility howsoever arising and will not be liable for any and all activities that occur under your account to the extent that they result from your failure to comply with this paragraph.

4. Cookies

As part of our high security standards, when you enter the Website we will use cookies. Cookies are small pieces of information that are stored on your computer, and are held until you close your browser, log off our Website, or the session automatically expires. The cookie does not contain any personal or confidential data about you. Most browsers are initially set up to accept cookies. You can set your browser to refuse cookies, however, if you choose this setting you will be unable to use our Website.

5. Service Activity Logging

All transactions conducted through the Website will be monitored and recorded for the purposes of logging Website usage, diagnosing problems, enhancing features and functionality of the Services and for other legitimate business purposes.

Security

Our Website is secured by firewalls and IDPS (Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems) to prevent the loss, misuse and alteration of the information under our control. Our web servers are located in a high security Data Centre professionally managed by a third party vendor. The servers on which we store personally-identifiable information are kept in a secure environment in independently-lockable racks. Our Data Centre has multi-layered physical access controls, CCTV surveillance and formal physical security access procedures.

This Website takes every precaution to protect our users' information. We use the highest level of Internet-standard encryption technology to ensure the confidentiality of your data during transmission and to protect it against tampering and message forgery. This process is known as SSL/TLS (Secure Sockets Layer/Transport Layer Security) and we are constantly updating our technology to provide you with the maximum practicable level of security. 

To check that you are in the secure area of our site, look in the bottom right of your browser and you will see a closed padlock or an unbroken key. You can inspect our certificate by clicking on this icon to verify that the site you are using is genuine.

Notification of Changes

If we decide to change our Privacy Policy, we will post those changes on this page and may place notices on other page of our Website, so that you are aware of the information we collect and how we use it at all times. Continued use of the Website will signify that you agree to any such changes. If at any point we decide to use or disclose information we have collected in a manner different from that stated at the time it was collected, we will notify you.

Transfer of data outside of the European Economic Area (EEA)

Where we transfer personal data to service providers or advisors outside of the EEA we will ensure that the recipient provides appropriate technical and organisational measures to safeguard against the unauthorised or unlawful processing of personal data and its accidental loss, destruction or damage. However, such information may be accessible by law enforcement agencies and other authorities in those countries to prevent and detect crime and comply with legal obligations.

Contact Information

If you have any questions about this privacy policy or the practices of this Website please send an email to support@benpal.com

© Copyright 2016 Jardine Lloyd Thompson Group plc

issue.name: SSL cookie without secure flag set
issue.issueBackground: If the secure flag is set on a cookie, then browsers will not submit the cookie in any requests that use an unencrypted HTTP connection, thereby preventing the cookie from being trivially intercepted by an attacker monitoring network traffic. If the secure flag is not set, then the cookie will be transmitted in clear-text if the user visits any HTTP URLs within the cookie's scope. An attacker may be able to induce this event by feeding a user suitable links, either directly or via another web site. Even if the domain which issued the cookie does not host any content that is accessed over HTTP, an attacker may be able to use links of the form http://example.com:443/ to perform the same attack.
issue.remediationBackground: The secure flag should be set on all cookies that are used for transmitting sensitive data when accessing content over HTTPS. If cookies are used to transmit session tokens, then areas of the application that are accessed over HTTPS should employ their own session handling mechanism, and the session tokens used should never be transmitted over unencrypted communications.
issue.issueDetail:
The following cookie was issued by the application and does not have the secure flag set:
  • benpal_context=%1e?ov%11?.i?`?Z$%18????c???    ?~w%07??!?Y%7f?US??"?+R?q??s?B(?y?%1eE?}?Q%17?)6??%1f??; path=/; HttpOnly
The cookie does not appear to contain a session token, which may reduce the risk associated with this issue. You should review the contents of the cookie to determine its function.

issue.name: Content type incorrectly stated
issue.issueBackground:
If a web response specifies an incorrect content type, then browsers may process the response in unexpected ways. If the specified content type is a renderable text-based format, then the browser will usually attempt to parse and render the response in that format. If the specified type is an image format, then the browser will usually detect the anomaly and will analyze the actual content and attempt to determine its MIME type. Either case can lead to unexpected results, and if the content contains any user-controllable data may lead to cross-site scripting or other client-side vulnerabilities.

In most cases, the presence of an incorrect content type statement does not constitute a security flaw, particularly if the response contains static content. You should review the contents of the response and the context in which it appears to determine whether any vulnerability exists.
issue.remediationBackground: For every response containing a message body, the application should include a single Content-type header which correctly and unambiguously states the MIME type of the content in the response body.
issue.issueDetail:
The response contains the following Content-type statement:
  • Content-Type: application/x-javascript
The response states that it contains script. However, it actually appears to contain unrecognized content.

issue.name: Email addresses disclosed
issue.issueBackground:
The presence of email addresses within application responses does not necessarily constitute a security vulnerability. Email addresses may appear intentionally within contact information, and many applications (such as web mail) include arbitrary third-party email addresses within their core content.

However, email addresses of developers and other individuals (whether appearing on-screen or hidden within page source) may disclose information that is useful to an attacker; for example, they may represent usernames that can be used at the application's login, and they may be used in social engineering attacks against the organization's personnel. Unnecessary or excessive disclosure of email addresses may also lead to an increase in the volume of spam email received.
issue.remediationBackground: You should review the email addresses being disclosed by the application, and consider removing any that are unnecessary, or replacing personal addresses with anonymous mailbox addresses (such as helpdesk@example.com).
issue.issueDetail:
The following email addresses were disclosed in the response:
  • noemail@benpal.com
  • removedata@benpal.com
  • support@benpal.com

issue.name: Cacheable HTTPS response
issue.issueBackground: Unless directed otherwise, browsers may store a local cached copy of content received from web servers. Some browsers, including Internet Explorer, cache content accessed via HTTPS. If sensitive information in application responses is stored in the local cache, then this may be retrieved by other users who have access to the same computer at a future time.
issue.remediationBackground:
The application should return caching directives instructing browsers not to store local copies of any sensitive data. Often, this can be achieved by configuring the web server to prevent caching for relevant paths within the web root. Alternatively, most web development platforms allow you to control the server's caching directives from within individual scripts. Ideally, the web server should return the following HTTP headers in all responses containing sensitive content:
  • Cache-control: no-store
  • Pragma: no-cache

issue.name: Email addresses disclosed
issue.issueBackground:
The presence of email addresses within application responses does not necessarily constitute a security vulnerability. Email addresses may appear intentionally within contact information, and many applications (such as web mail) include arbitrary third-party email addresses within their core content.

However, email addresses of developers and other individuals (whether appearing on-screen or hidden within page source) may disclose information that is useful to an attacker; for example, they may represent usernames that can be used at the application's login, and they may be used in social engineering attacks against the organization's personnel. Unnecessary or excessive disclosure of email addresses may also lead to an increase in the volume of spam email received.
issue.remediationBackground: You should review the email addresses being disclosed by the application, and consider removing any that are unnecessary, or replacing personal addresses with anonymous mailbox addresses (such as helpdesk@example.com).
issue.issueDetail:
The following email address was disclosed in the response:

issue.name: Frameable response (potential Clickjacking)
issue.issueBackground:
It might be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the content of this response within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may enable a "clickjacking" attack, in which the attacker's page overlays the target application's interface with a different interface provided by the attacker. By inducing victim users to perform actions such as mouse clicks and keystrokes, the attacker can cause them to unwittingly carry out actions within the application that is being targeted. This technique allows the attacker to circumvent defenses against cross-site request forgery, and may result in unauthorized actions.

Note that this issue is being reported because the application's response does not set a suitable X-Frame-Options header in order to prevent framing attacks. Some applications attempt to prevent these attacks from within the HTML page itself, using "framebusting" code. However, this type of defense is normally ineffective and can usually be circumvented by a skilled attacker.
issue.remediationBackground:
You should review the application functions that are accessible from within the response, and determine whether they can be used by application users to perform any sensitive actions within the application. If so, then a framing attack targeting this response may result in unauthorized actions.

To effectively prevent framing attacks, the application should return a response header with the name X-Frame-Options and the value DENY to prevent framing altogether, or the value SAMEORIGIN to allow framing only by pages on the same origin as the response itself.

issue.name: Robots.txt file
issue.issueBackground:
The file robots.txt is used to give instructions to web robots, such as search engine crawlers, about locations within the web site which robots are allowed, or not allowed, to crawl and index.

The presence of the robots.txt does not in itself present any kind of security vulnerability. However, it is often used to identify restricted or private areas of a site's contents. The information in the file may therefore help an attacker to map out the site's contents, especially if some of the locations identified are not linked from elsewhere in the site. If the application relies on robots.txt to protect access to these areas, and does not enforce proper access control over them, then this presents a serious vulnerability.
issue.remediationBackground: The robots.txt file is not itself a security threat, and its correct use can represent good practice for non-security reasons. You should not assume that all web robots will honor the file's instructions. Rather, assume that attackers will pay close attention to any locations identified in the file. Do not rely on robots.txt to provide any kind of protection over unauthorized access.
issue.issueDetail: The web server contains a robots.txt file.

issue.name: SSL cookie without secure flag set
issue.issueBackground: If the secure flag is set on a cookie, then browsers will not submit the cookie in any requests that use an unencrypted HTTP connection, thereby preventing the cookie from being trivially intercepted by an attacker monitoring network traffic. If the secure flag is not set, then the cookie will be transmitted in clear-text if the user visits any HTTP URLs within the cookie's scope. An attacker may be able to induce this event by feeding a user suitable links, either directly or via another web site. Even if the domain which issued the cookie does not host any content that is accessed over HTTP, an attacker may be able to use links of the form http://example.com:443/ to perform the same attack.
issue.remediationBackground: The secure flag should be set on all cookies that are used for transmitting sensitive data when accessing content over HTTPS. If cookies are used to transmit session tokens, then areas of the application that are accessed over HTTPS should employ their own session handling mechanism, and the session tokens used should never be transmitted over unencrypted communications.

issue.name: SSL cookie without secure flag set
issue.issueBackground: If the secure flag is set on a cookie, then browsers will not submit the cookie in any requests that use an unencrypted HTTP connection, thereby preventing the cookie from being trivially intercepted by an attacker monitoring network traffic. If the secure flag is not set, then the cookie will be transmitted in clear-text if the user visits any HTTP URLs within the cookie's scope. An attacker may be able to induce this event by feeding a user suitable links, either directly or via another web site. Even if the domain which issued the cookie does not host any content that is accessed over HTTP, an attacker may be able to use links of the form http://example.com:443/ to perform the same attack.
issue.remediationBackground: The secure flag should be set on all cookies that are used for transmitting sensitive data when accessing content over HTTPS. If cookies are used to transmit session tokens, then areas of the application that are accessed over HTTPS should employ their own session handling mechanism, and the session tokens used should never be transmitted over unencrypted communications.

issue.name: Email addresses disclosed
issue.issueBackground:
The presence of email addresses within application responses does not necessarily constitute a security vulnerability. Email addresses may appear intentionally within contact information, and many applications (such as web mail) include arbitrary third-party email addresses within their core content.

However, email addresses of developers and other individuals (whether appearing on-screen or hidden within page source) may disclose information that is useful to an attacker; for example, they may represent usernames that can be used at the application's login, and they may be used in social engineering attacks against the organization's personnel. Unnecessary or excessive disclosure of email addresses may also lead to an increase in the volume of spam email received.
issue.remediationBackground: You should review the email addresses being disclosed by the application, and consider removing any that are unnecessary, or replacing personal addresses with anonymous mailbox addresses (such as helpdesk@example.com).

issue.name: Content type incorrectly stated
issue.issueBackground:
If a web response specifies an incorrect content type, then browsers may process the response in unexpected ways. If the specified content type is a renderable text-based format, then the browser will usually attempt to parse and render the response in that format. If the specified type is an image format, then the browser will usually detect the anomaly and will analyze the actual content and attempt to determine its MIME type. Either case can lead to unexpected results, and if the content contains any user-controllable data may lead to cross-site scripting or other client-side vulnerabilities.

In most cases, the presence of an incorrect content type statement does not constitute a security flaw, particularly if the response contains static content. You should review the contents of the response and the context in which it appears to determine whether any vulnerability exists.
issue.remediationBackground: For every response containing a message body, the application should include a single Content-type header which correctly and unambiguously states the MIME type of the content in the response body.
issue.issueDetail:
The response contains the following Content-type statement:
  • Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
The response states that it contains plain text. However, it actually appears to contain script.

issue.name: Frameable response (potential Clickjacking)
issue.issueBackground:
It might be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the content of this response within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may enable a "clickjacking" attack, in which the attacker's page overlays the target application's interface with a different interface provided by the attacker. By inducing victim users to perform actions such as mouse clicks and keystrokes, the attacker can cause them to unwittingly carry out actions within the application that is being targeted. This technique allows the attacker to circumvent defenses against cross-site request forgery, and may result in unauthorized actions.

Note that this issue is being reported because the application's response does not set a suitable X-Frame-Options header in order to prevent framing attacks. Some applications attempt to prevent these attacks from within the HTML page itself, using "framebusting" code. However, this type of defense is normally ineffective and can usually be circumvented by a skilled attacker.
issue.remediationBackground:
You should review the application functions that are accessible from within the response, and determine whether they can be used by application users to perform any sensitive actions within the application. If so, then a framing attack targeting this response may result in unauthorized actions.

To effectively prevent framing attacks, the application should return a response header with the name X-Frame-Options and the value DENY to prevent framing altogether, or the value SAMEORIGIN to allow framing only by pages on the same origin as the response itself.

BenPal￢ﾄﾢ Your benefits friend

Privacy

JLT Benefit Solutions Limited ("JLTBS", "our," "us" and "we") has created this privacy policy in order to communicate our commitment to the privacy of information provided to us by our employer clients and their employees. We understand the nature of the information entrusted to us and acknowledge that maintenance of the privacy of such information is of the highest importance to our clients and their employees. The following discloses our information gathering and dissemination practices in relation to the services we provide through or in connection with the website that you have accessed using the special benefits icon, https://www.benpal.com ("Website" and "our Services").

Our Information Practices

We collect, use and disclose the following categories of information in the following ways:

1. Company Contact Information

When clients and prospective clients engage us or inquire about our Services, we ask them to provide us with company contact information, some examples of which are the company's name, address, number of employees and industry classification. We use company contact information to provide information to clients and prospective clients (paper and electronic) in relation to our Services and to maintain a record of inquiries regarding our Services.

2. Information we collect and how we use it

When your employer decides to use our Services to enable you to join and manage your employee benefits, your employer provides us with information which includes, but is not limited to, your name, address, NI number, title, salary, commencement of employment and information regarding your employment. We may also ask for details of your spouse, partner or other immediate family member if they are to be included as the beneficiary of a policy or product. Where you submit such details, you do so on behalf of the relevant family member and you acknowledge and accept that it is your responsibility for letting them know (i) that you have done so, (ii) what details you have submitted and (iii) the purpose of submitting the details. It is your responsibility to keep your personal details and those of any relevant family member updated. If we require sensitive personal data, we will ensure that the collection and use is in strict accordance with the "application legislation" principles of data protection and data privacy.

If you do not wish us to hold your personal data in order to use our Services, please send a blank email to removedata@benpal.com

We gather this information to allow us to process your enrolment, provide you with updated details of your employee benefits, to assist you in applying for further benefits or products and to allow us to process those applications. When you apply for any benefits and/or products offered through the Website, we will pass your personal details and those of your beneficiary, where applicable, to the provider of those benefits and/or products. Thereafter, the provider may correspond with you directly. Information we have gathered from your employer and you may also be used by us to communicate with you on any matter relating to your benefits and the provision of our Services in general.

Your employer has provided us with your business e-mail address in order for us to communicate your benefit offering and our services. E-mail messages sent over the Internet cannot be guaranteed to be completely secure as they may be subject to possible interception or loss. If you do not want to be contacted on your business e-mail address, please send a blank email to noemail@benpal.com

We may also aggregate employee information from multiple employer clients to monitor Website usage, assist us to develop our services and to analyse performance. Examples of analyses performed include, but are not limited to: number of employees enrolled in plans provided by a particular insurance carrier, average number of employees employed by our clients and average number of benefit plans sponsored by our clients. When used to perform such analyses, information provided by an employer customer or its employees is never disclosed in a level of detail sufficient to permit the identification of any individual employer customer or individual employee record.

From time to time, we may provide your information to our client service agencies for research and analysis purposes so that we can monitor and improve the service we provide. We, or our agents and sub-contractors may contact you by post, e-mail or telephone to ask you for your feedback and comments on our service.

We may also wish to provide you with information about special features of our Website, our Services or other services. If you do not want to receive this information go to "My Account" and select "Preferences" to turn this service off.

3. Login Identification/Passwords

Our Services require users to choose a username and password in order to activate their account and these will be the login credentials to access the Website. You agree to maintain the confidentiality of your username and password and agreed to notify us immediately should you become aware of any unauthorised use of your username, password, account or information on the Website. You are responsible for the security of your username and password and JLT accepts no responsibility howsoever arising and will not be liable for any and all activities that occur under your account to the extent that they result from your failure to comply with this paragraph.

4. Cookies

As part of our high security standards, when you enter the Website we will use cookies. Cookies are small pieces of information that are stored on your computer, and are held until you close your browser, log off our Website, or the session automatically expires. The cookie does not contain any personal or confidential data about you. Most browsers are initially set up to accept cookies. You can set your browser to refuse cookies, however, if you choose this setting you will be unable to use our Website.

5. Service Activity Logging

All transactions conducted through the Website will be monitored and recorded for the purposes of logging Website usage, diagnosing problems, enhancing features and functionality of the Services and for other legitimate business purposes.

Security

Our Website is secured by firewalls and IDPS (Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems) to prevent the loss, misuse and alteration of the information under our control. Our web servers are located in a high security Data Centre professionally managed by a third party vendor. The servers on which we store personally-identifiable information are kept in a secure environment in independently-lockable racks. Our Data Centre has multi-layered physical access controls, CCTV surveillance and formal physical security access procedures.

This Website takes every precaution to protect our users' information. We use the highest level of Internet-standard encryption technology to ensure the confidentiality of your data during transmission and to protect it against tampering and message forgery. This process is known as SSL/TLS (Secure Sockets Layer/Transport Layer Security) and we are constantly updating our technology to provide you with the maximum practicable level of security. 

To check that you are in the secure area of our site, look in the bottom right of your browser and you will see a closed padlock or an unbroken key. You can inspect our certificate by clicking on this icon to verify that the site you are using is genuine.

Notification of Changes

If we decide to change our Privacy Policy, we will post those changes on this page and may place notices on other page of our Website, so that you are aware of the information we collect and how we use it at all times. Continued use of the Website will signify that you agree to any such changes. If at any point we decide to use or disclose information we have collected in a manner different from that stated at the time it was collected, we will notify you.

Transfer of data outside of the European Economic Area (EEA)

Where we transfer personal data to service providers or advisors outside of the EEA we will ensure that the recipient provides appropriate technical and organisational measures to safeguard against the unauthorised or unlawful processing of personal data and its accidental loss, destruction or damage. However, such information may be accessible by law enforcement agencies and other authorities in those countries to prevent and detect crime and comply with legal obligations.

Contact Information

If you have any questions about this privacy policy or the practices of this Website please send an email to support@benpal.com

issue.name: Email addresses disclosed
issue.issueBackground:
The presence of email addresses within application responses does not necessarily constitute a security vulnerability. Email addresses may appear intentionally within contact information, and many applications (such as web mail) include arbitrary third-party email addresses within their core content.

However, email addresses of developers and other individuals (whether appearing on-screen or hidden within page source) may disclose information that is useful to an attacker; for example, they may represent usernames that can be used at the application's login, and they may be used in social engineering attacks against the organization's personnel. Unnecessary or excessive disclosure of email addresses may also lead to an increase in the volume of spam email received.
issue.remediationBackground: You should review the email addresses being disclosed by the application, and consider removing any that are unnecessary, or replacing personal addresses with anonymous mailbox addresses (such as helpdesk@example.com).
issue.issueDetail:
The following email addresses were disclosed in the response:
  • noemail@benpal.com
  • removedata@benpal.com
  • support@benpal.com

issue.name: SSL cookie without secure flag set
issue.issueBackground: If the secure flag is set on a cookie, then browsers will not submit the cookie in any requests that use an unencrypted HTTP connection, thereby preventing the cookie from being trivially intercepted by an attacker monitoring network traffic. If the secure flag is not set, then the cookie will be transmitted in clear-text if the user visits any HTTP URLs within the cookie's scope. An attacker may be able to induce this event by feeding a user suitable links, either directly or via another web site. Even if the domain which issued the cookie does not host any content that is accessed over HTTP, an attacker may be able to use links of the form http://example.com:443/ to perform the same attack.
issue.remediationBackground: The secure flag should be set on all cookies that are used for transmitting sensitive data when accessing content over HTTPS. If cookies are used to transmit session tokens, then areas of the application that are accessed over HTTPS should employ their own session handling mechanism, and the session tokens used should never be transmitted over unencrypted communications.

issue.name: Email addresses disclosed
issue.issueBackground:
The presence of email addresses within application responses does not necessarily constitute a security vulnerability. Email addresses may appear intentionally within contact information, and many applications (such as web mail) include arbitrary third-party email addresses within their core content.

However, email addresses of developers and other individuals (whether appearing on-screen or hidden within page source) may disclose information that is useful to an attacker; for example, they may represent usernames that can be used at the application's login, and they may be used in social engineering attacks against the organization's personnel. Unnecessary or excessive disclosure of email addresses may also lead to an increase in the volume of spam email received.
issue.remediationBackground: You should review the email addresses being disclosed by the application, and consider removing any that are unnecessary, or replacing personal addresses with anonymous mailbox addresses (such as helpdesk@example.com).

issue.name: Frameable response (potential Clickjacking)
issue.issueBackground:
It might be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the content of this response within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may enable a "clickjacking" attack, in which the attacker's page overlays the target application's interface with a different interface provided by the attacker. By inducing victim users to perform actions such as mouse clicks and keystrokes, the attacker can cause them to unwittingly carry out actions within the application that is being targeted. This technique allows the attacker to circumvent defenses against cross-site request forgery, and may result in unauthorized actions.

Note that this issue is being reported because the application's response does not set a suitable X-Frame-Options header in order to prevent framing attacks. Some applications attempt to prevent these attacks from within the HTML page itself, using "framebusting" code. However, this type of defense is normally ineffective and can usually be circumvented by a skilled attacker.
issue.remediationBackground:
You should review the application functions that are accessible from within the response, and determine whether they can be used by application users to perform any sensitive actions within the application. If so, then a framing attack targeting this response may result in unauthorized actions.

To effectively prevent framing attacks, the application should return a response header with the name X-Frame-Options and the value DENY to prevent framing altogether, or the value SAMEORIGIN to allow framing only by pages on the same origin as the response itself.

issue.name: SSL cookie without secure flag set
issue.issueBackground: If the secure flag is set on a cookie, then browsers will not submit the cookie in any requests that use an unencrypted HTTP connection, thereby preventing the cookie from being trivially intercepted by an attacker monitoring network traffic. If the secure flag is not set, then the cookie will be transmitted in clear-text if the user visits any HTTP URLs within the cookie's scope. An attacker may be able to induce this event by feeding a user suitable links, either directly or via another web site. Even if the domain which issued the cookie does not host any content that is accessed over HTTP, an attacker may be able to use links of the form http://example.com:443/ to perform the same attack.
issue.remediationBackground: The secure flag should be set on all cookies that are used for transmitting sensitive data when accessing content over HTTPS. If cookies are used to transmit session tokens, then areas of the application that are accessed over HTTPS should employ their own session handling mechanism, and the session tokens used should never be transmitted over unencrypted communications.

issue.name: SSL certificate
issue.issueBackground:
SSL helps to protect the confidentiality and integrity of information in transit between the browser and server, and to provide authentication of the server's identity. To serve this purpose, the server must present an SSL certificate which is valid for the server's hostname, is issued by a trusted authority and is valid for the current date. If any one of these requirements is not met, SSL connections to the server will not provide the full protection for which SSL is designed.

It should be noted that various attacks exist against SSL in general, and in the context of HTTPS web connections. It may be possible for a determined and suitably-positioned attacker to compromise SSL connections without user detection even when a valid SSL certificate is used.
issue.issueDetail:
The server presented a valid, trusted SSL certificate. This issue is purely informational.

To effectively prevent framing attacks, the application should return a response header with the name X-Frame-Options and the value DENY to prevent framing altogether, or the value SAMEORIGIN to allow framing only by pages on the same origin as the response itself.

BenPal￢ﾄﾢ Your benefits friend

Privacy

JLT Benefit Solutions Limited ("JLTBS", "our," "us" and "we") has created this privacy policy in order to communicate our commitment to the privacy of information provided to us by our employer clients and their employees. We understand the nature of the information entrusted to us and acknowledge that maintenance of the privacy of such information is of the highest importance to our clients and their employees. The following discloses our information gathering and dissemination practices in relation to the services we provide through or in connection with the website that you have accessed using the special benefits icon, https://www.benpal.com ("Website" and "our Services").

Our Information Practices

We collect, use and disclose the following categories of information in the following ways:

1. Company Contact Information

When clients and prospective clients engage us or inquire about our Services, we ask them to provide us with company contact information, some examples of which are the company's name, address, number of employees and industry classification. We use company contact information to provide information to clients and prospective clients (paper and electronic) in relation to our Services and to maintain a record of inquiries regarding our Services.

2. Information we collect and how we use it

When your employer decides to use our Services to enable you to join and manage your employee benefits, your employer provides us with information which includes, but is not limited to, your name, address, NI number, title, salary, commencement of employment and information regarding your employment. We may also ask for details of your spouse, partner or other immediate family member if they are to be included as the beneficiary of a policy or product. Where you submit such details, you do so on behalf of the relevant family member and you acknowledge and accept that it is your responsibility for letting them know (i) that you have done so, (ii) what details you have submitted and (iii) the purpose of submitting the details. It is your responsibility to keep your personal details and those of any relevant family member updated. If we require sensitive personal data, we will ensure that the collection and use is in strict accordance with the "application legislation" principles of data protection and data privacy.

If you do not wish us to hold your personal data in order to use our Services, please send a blank email to removedata@benpal.com

We gather this information to allow us to process your enrolment, provide you with updated details of your employee benefits, to assist you in applying for further benefits or products and to allow us to process those applications. When you apply for any benefits and/or products offered through the Website, we will pass your personal details and those of your beneficiary, where applicable, to the provider of those benefits and/or products. Thereafter, the provider may correspond with you directly. Information we have gathered from your employer and you may also be used by us to communicate with you on any matter relating to your benefits and the provision of our Services in general.

Your employer has provided us with your business e-mail address in order for us to communicate your benefit offering and our services. E-mail messages sent over the Internet cannot be guaranteed to be completely secure as they may be subject to possible interception or loss. If you do not want to be contacted on your business e-mail address, please send a blank email to noemail@benpal.com

We may also aggregate employee information from multiple employer clients to monitor Website usage, assist us to develop our services and to analyse performance. Examples of analyses performed include, but are not limited to: number of employees enrolled in plans provided by a particular insurance carrier, average number of employees employed by our clients and average number of benefit plans sponsored by our clients. When used to perform such analyses, information provided by an employer customer or its employees is never disclosed in a level of detail sufficient to permit the identification of any individual employer customer or individual employee record.

From time to time, we may provide your information to our client service agencies for research and analysis purposes so that we can monitor and improve the service we provide. We, or our agents and sub-contractors may contact you by post, e-mail or telephone to ask you for your feedback and comments on our service.

We may also wish to provide you with information about special features of our Website, our Services or other services. If you do not want to receive this information go to "My Account" and select "Preferences" to turn this service off.

3. Login Identification/Passwords

Our Services require users to choose a username and password in order to activate their account and these will be the login credentials to access the Website. You agree to maintain the confidentiality of your username and password and agreed to notify us immediately should you become aware of any unauthorised use of your username, password, account or information on the Website. You are responsible for the security of your username and password and JLT accepts no responsibility howsoever arising and will not be liable for any and all activities that occur under your account to the extent that they result from your failure to comply with this paragraph.

4. Cookies

As part of our high security standards, when you enter the Website we will use cookies. Cookies are small pieces of information that are stored on your computer, and are held until you close your browser, log off our Website, or the session automatically expires. The cookie does not contain any personal or confidential data about you. Most browsers are initially set up to accept cookies. You can set your browser to refuse cookies, however, if you choose this setting you will be unable to use our Website.

5. Service Activity Logging

All transactions conducted through the Website will be monitored and recorded for the purposes of logging Website usage, diagnosing problems, enhancing features and functionality of the Services and for other legitimate business purposes.

Security

Our Website is secured by firewalls and IDPS (Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems) to prevent the loss, misuse and alteration of the information under our control. Our web servers are located in a high security Data Centre professionally managed by a third party vendor. The servers on which we store personally-identifiable information are kept in a secure environment in independently-lockable racks. Our Data Centre has multi-layered physical access controls, CCTV surveillance and formal physical security access procedures.

This Website takes every precaution to protect our users' information. We use the highest level of Internet-standard encryption technology to ensure the confidentiality of your data during transmission and to protect it against tampering and message forgery. This process is known as SSL/TLS (Secure Sockets Layer/Transport Layer Security) and we are constantly updating our technology to provide you with the maximum practicable level of security. 

To check that you are in the secure area of our site, look in the bottom right of your browser and you will see a closed padlock or an unbroken key. You can inspect our certificate by clicking on this icon to verify that the site you are using is genuine.

Notification of Changes

If we decide to change our Privacy Policy, we will post those changes on this page and may place notices on other page of our Website, so that you are aware of the information we collect and how we use it at all times. Continued use of the Website will signify that you agree to any such changes. If at any point we decide to use or disclose information we have collected in a manner different from that stated at the time it was collected, we will notify you.

Transfer of data outside of the European Economic Area (EEA)

Where we transfer personal data to service providers or advisors outside of the EEA we will ensure that the recipient provides appropriate technical and organisational measures to safeguard against the unauthorised or unlawful processing of personal data and its accidental loss, destruction or damage. However, such information may be accessible by law enforcement agencies and other authorities in those countries to prevent and detect crime and comply with legal obligations.

Contact Information

If you have any questions about this privacy policy or the practices of this Website please send an email to support@benpal.com

issue.name: Email addresses disclosed
issue.issueBackground:
The presence of email addresses within application responses does not necessarily constitute a security vulnerability. Email addresses may appear intentionally within contact information, and many applications (such as web mail) include arbitrary third-party email addresses within their core content.

However, email addresses of developers and other individuals (whether appearing on-screen or hidden within page source) may disclose information that is useful to an attacker; for example, they may represent usernames that can be used at the application's login, and they may be used in social engineering attacks against the organization's personnel. Unnecessary or excessive disclosure of email addresses may also lead to an increase in the volume of spam email received.
issue.remediationBackground: You should review the email addresses being disclosed by the application, and consider removing any that are unnecessary, or replacing personal addresses with anonymous mailbox addresses (such as helpdesk@example.com).

issue.name: SSL cookie without secure flag set
issue.issueBackground: If the secure flag is set on a cookie, then browsers will not submit the cookie in any requests that use an unencrypted HTTP connection, thereby preventing the cookie from being trivially intercepted by an attacker monitoring network traffic. If the secure flag is not set, then the cookie will be transmitted in clear-text if the user visits any HTTP URLs within the cookie's scope. An attacker may be able to induce this event by feeding a user suitable links, either directly or via another web site. Even if the domain which issued the cookie does not host any content that is accessed over HTTP, an attacker may be able to use links of the form http://example.com:443/ to perform the same attack.
issue.remediationBackground: The secure flag should be set on all cookies that are used for transmitting sensitive data when accessing content over HTTPS. If cookies are used to transmit session tokens, then areas of the application that are accessed over HTTPS should employ their own session handling mechanism, and the session tokens used should never be transmitted over unencrypted communications.
issue.issueDetail:
The following cookie was issued by the application and does not have the secure flag set:
  • benpal_context=??Xf?%0e?%1b?}?y?????:?3\<?}?%02pr>;????DvF5%0bU`?pI??S?%1c?%01$; path=/; HttpOnly
The cookie does not appear to contain a session token, which may reduce the risk associated with this issue. You should review the contents of the cookie to determine its function.

issue.name: Frameable response (potential Clickjacking)
issue.issueBackground:
It might be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the content of this response within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may enable a "clickjacking" attack, in which the attacker's page overlays the target application's interface with a different interface provided by the attacker. By inducing victim users to perform actions such as mouse clicks and keystrokes, the attacker can cause them to unwittingly carry out actions within the application that is being targeted. This technique allows the attacker to circumvent defenses against cross-site request forgery, and may result in unauthorized actions.

Note that this issue is being reported because the application's response does not set a suitable X-Frame-Options header in order to prevent framing attacks. Some applications attempt to prevent these attacks from within the HTML page itself, using "framebusting" code. However, this type of defense is normally ineffective and can usually be circumvented by a skilled attacker.
issue.remediationBackground:
You should review the application functions that are accessible from within the response, and determine whether they can be used by application users to perform any sensitive actions within the application. If so, then a framing attack targeting this response may result in unauthorized actions.

To effectively prevent framing attacks, the application should return a response header with the name X-Frame-Options and the value DENY to prevent framing altogether, or the value SAMEORIGIN to allow framing only by pages on the same origin as the response itself.

BenPal￢ﾄﾢ Your benefits friend

Accessibility

JLT Online Benefits aims to give all users a simple and user-friendly experience in the BenPal website.

To ensure this is the case, we have designed the site with a variety of accessibility features to make it easier to view and navigate for people with poor eyesight, blindness or other physical disabilities.

Please let us know if you have any questions, suggestions or other feedback to help us continue to improve the experience for all BenPal users.

The table below highlights some of the features that have been built in to the site to help navigation and usability through text-only browsers, keyboard navigation and for screen reader users.

Images

  • All content images have descriptive alt attributes
  • Solely decorative graphics have empty alt attributes

Font sizes

Change size through your browser:

  • Internet Explorer - select View, Text Size and then choose the preferred size
  • Firefox – select View, Zoom, Zoom In/Out

Forms

  • All forms follow a logical tab sequence
  • All labels that are associated with fields use HTML label tabs.

Scripting

Javascript is used to enhance usability but it is possible to browse the site without Javascript. All labels that are associated with fields use HTML label tabs.

Useful information

  • W3 Accessibility Guidelines
  • RNIB Web Accessibility

If you have a disability, you can get additional software and equipment to help you use your computer and gain more access to websites:

  • Links – free text-only web browser for sighted users with low bandwidth
  • Lynx – free text-only web browser for blind users with refreshable Braille displays
  • JAWS – screen reader for Windows
  • VoiceOver – screen reader for Mac
  • Windows-Eyes – screen reader for Windows

issue.name: HTML5 cross-origin resource sharing
issue.issueBackground:
The HTML5 cross-origin resource sharing policy controls whether and how content running on other domains can perform two-way interaction with the domain which publishes the policy. The policy is fine-grained and can apply access controls per-request based on the URL and other features of the request.

If another domain is allowed by the policy, then that domain can potentially attack users of the application. If a user is logged in to the application, and visits a domain allowed by the policy, then any malicious content running on that domain can potentially retrieve content from the application, and sometimes carry out actions within the security context of the logged in user.

Even if an allowed domain is not overtly malicious in itself, security vulnerabilities within that domain could potentially be leveraged by a third-party attacker to exploit the trust relationship and attack the application which allows access.
issue.remediationBackground: You should review the domains which are allowed by the CORS policy in relation to any sensitive content within the application, and determine whether it is appropriate for the application to trust both the intentions and security posture of those domains.
issue.issueDetail:
The application implements an HTML5 cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) policy for this request which allows access from any domain.

Allowing access from all domains means that any domain can perform two-way interaction with the application via this request. Unless the response consists only of unprotected public content, this policy is likely to present a security risk.

Note: The application does not issue an Access-Control-Allow-Credentials header allowing two-way in-session interaction. Without this header in the response, although client code can initiate cross-domain with-cookies requests to the target, the code will not be able to read responses from with-cookies requests. This constraint mitigates the impact of this behavior in relation to cross-domain retrieval of sensitive in-session data.

issue.name: SSL cookie without secure flag set
issue.issueBackground: If the secure flag is set on a cookie, then browsers will not submit the cookie in any requests that use an unencrypted HTTP connection, thereby preventing the cookie from being trivially intercepted by an attacker monitoring network traffic. If the secure flag is not set, then the cookie will be transmitted in clear-text if the user visits any HTTP URLs within the cookie's scope. An attacker may be able to induce this event by feeding a user suitable links, either directly or via another web site. Even if the domain which issued the cookie does not host any content that is accessed over HTTP, an attacker may be able to use links of the form http://example.com:443/ to perform the same attack.
issue.remediationBackground: The secure flag should be set on all cookies that are used for transmitting sensitive data when accessing content over HTTPS. If cookies are used to transmit session tokens, then areas of the application that are accessed over HTTPS should employ their own session handling mechanism, and the session tokens used should never be transmitted over unencrypted communications.

issue.name: Email addresses disclosed
issue.issueBackground:
The presence of email addresses within application responses does not necessarily constitute a security vulnerability. Email addresses may appear intentionally within contact information, and many applications (such as web mail) include arbitrary third-party email addresses within their core content.

However, email addresses of developers and other individuals (whether appearing on-screen or hidden within page source) may disclose information that is useful to an attacker; for example, they may represent usernames that can be used at the application's login, and they may be used in social engineering attacks against the organization's personnel. Unnecessary or excessive disclosure of email addresses may also lead to an increase in the volume of spam email received.
issue.remediationBackground: You should review the email addresses being disclosed by the application, and consider removing any that are unnecessary, or replacing personal addresses with anonymous mailbox addresses (such as helpdesk@example.com).
issue.issueDetail:
The following email address was disclosed in the response:

issue.name: Frameable response (potential Clickjacking)
issue.issueBackground:
It might be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the content of this response within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may enable a "clickjacking" attack, in which the attacker's page overlays the target application's interface with a different interface provided by the attacker. By inducing victim users to perform actions such as mouse clicks and keystrokes, the attacker can cause them to unwittingly carry out actions within the application that is being targeted. This technique allows the attacker to circumvent defenses against cross-site request forgery, and may result in unauthorized actions.

Note that this issue is being reported because the application's response does not set a suitable X-Frame-Options header in order to prevent framing attacks. Some applications attempt to prevent these attacks from within the HTML page itself, using "framebusting" code. However, this type of defense is normally ineffective and can usually be circumvented by a skilled attacker.
issue.remediationBackground:
You should review the application functions that are accessible from within the response, and determine whether they can be used by application users to perform any sensitive actions within the application. If so, then a framing attack targeting this response may result in unauthorized actions.

To effectively prevent framing attacks, the application should return a response header with the name X-Frame-Options and the value DENY to prevent framing altogether, or the value SAMEORIGIN to allow framing only by pages on the same origin as the response itself.

issue.name: Email addresses disclosed
issue.issueBackground:
The presence of email addresses within application responses does not necessarily constitute a security vulnerability. Email addresses may appear intentionally within contact information, and many applications (such as web mail) include arbitrary third-party email addresses within their core content.

However, email addresses of developers and other individuals (whether appearing on-screen or hidden within page source) may disclose information that is useful to an attacker; for example, they may represent usernames that can be used at the application's login, and they may be used in social engineering attacks against the organization's personnel. Unnecessary or excessive disclosure of email addresses may also lead to an increase in the volume of spam email received.
issue.remediationBackground: You should review the email addresses being disclosed by the application, and consider removing any that are unnecessary, or replacing personal addresses with anonymous mailbox addresses (such as helpdesk@example.com).
issue.issueDetail:
The following email address was disclosed in the response:
  • support@benpal.com

issue.name: Frameable response (potential Clickjacking)
issue.issueBackground:
It might be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the content of this response within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may enable a "clickjacking" attack, in which the attacker's page overlays the target application's interface with a different interface provided by the attacker. By inducing victim users to perform actions such as mouse clicks and keystrokes, the attacker can cause them to unwittingly carry out actions within the application that is being targeted. This technique allows the attacker to circumvent defenses against cross-site request forgery, and may result in unauthorized actions.

Note that this issue is being reported because the application's response does not set a suitable X-Frame-Options header in order to prevent framing attacks. Some applications attempt to prevent these attacks from within the HTML page itself, using "framebusting" code. However, this type of defense is normally ineffective and can usually be circumvented by a skilled attacker.
issue.remediationBackground:
You should review the application functions that are accessible from within the response, and determine whether they can be used by application users to perform any sensitive actions within the application. If so, then a framing attack targeting this response may result in unauthorized actions.

To effectively prevent framing attacks, the application should return a response header with the name X-Frame-Options and the value DENY to prevent framing altogether, or the value SAMEORIGIN to allow framing only by pages on the same origin as the response itself.
